title: CKD Prediction in HIV+ Patients
description: Determines likelihood of HIV patients developing CKD in the next 5 years, whether they take tenofovir or not

ranges.interpretation: Consider tenofovir use with routine monitoring
Careful consideration of tenofovir risks and benefits
Strong consideration for alternative to tenofovir

references: Scherzer R, Gandhi M, Estrella MM, Tien PC, Deeks SG, Grunfeld C, Peralta CA, Shlipak MG. A chronic kidney disease risk score to determine tenofovir safety in a prospective cohort of HIV-positive male veterans. AIDS. 2014;28(9):1289-95.

Mocroft A, Lundgren JD, Ross M, Law M, Reiss P, Kirk O, Smith C, Wentworth D, Neuhaus J, Fux CA, Moranne O, Morlat P, Johnson MA, Ryom L; D:A:D Study Group. Development and validation of a risk score for chronic kidney disease in HIV infection using prospective cohort data from the D:A:D study. PLoS Med. 2015;12(3):e1001809.
formula: Sum of risk factor points: Age (0-6) + Glucose >140 (2) + SBP >140 (1) + Hypertension (2) + Triglycerides >200 (1) + Proteinuria (2) + CD4+ <200 (1). 5-year CKD risk based on total score and tenofovir use status.
notes: Based on prospective cohort study of HIV-positive male veterans
Helps guide clinical decision-making around tenofovir use
Traditional kidney risk factors are dominant contributors
CD4+ count included but HIV RNA viral load is not a component
Number needed to harm (NNH) for tenofovir decreases with higher scores
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment
Regular monitoring of kidney function recommended regardless of risk score
